int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"The parent education program was designed to support child development in
different areas. Accordingly, the program topics were chosen by considering
parent needs and included the following: personality development for child
development and education, language development, cognitive development,
sexual development, social development, motor development, parent-child
communication, sibling relationships, behavioral disorders, discipline, games-
toys-books, accidents, home activities, childhood illnesses, and nutrition. The
program was then evaluated by nine field experts and the program was finalized
in line with their feedback. The parent education program was implemented in
the experimental group as informational sessions once weekly for a duration of
8 weeks. In order to assist parents in supporting their children’s development,
relevant brochures were distributed to parents, and they were given tasks to
carry out at home with their children. In addition, there were sessions held to
discuss the topics of behavioral problems, sexual development, parent-child
communication, and discipline.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"The aim of parent education is to maximize
their children’s academic and life success, and to prepare them for life as
contented and accomplished individuals[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"At the time of the study HIPPY was a two-year program. Most children were four years old at the beginning of the program and attended kindergarten during its second year. Thus, the program was designed to span the transition from preschool to formal elementary school. In each year of the program, there were 30 weeks of activities, scheduled to coincide with the school year."
"Lombard designed the program for
mothers to deliver the HIPPY lessons to their children (as opposed to a home vis-
itor working with the children directly). By learning how to teach their child and
by having successful teaching experiences, the goal was for HIPPY mothers to
gain confidence, interest, and skills to help their children succeed academically
even after the completion of the two year HIPPY program."
"Over the course of the program, mothers received a series of books written spe-
cifically for the HIPPY program along with activity packets. Each day, mothers
were to read to their children from one of the books and administer one set of activ-
ities (approximately two to three pages of guided instructions for the mother to
work on with her child). These activities ranged from a series of questions the
mother was to ask the child, along with possible responses; connect the dot activi-
ties; identifying the appropriate object from a printed matrix (e.g., find the girl
with the hat from a matrix of boys and girls with and without hats); and coloring
activities. The HIPPY activities were structured like a detailed lesson plan to guide
mothers in what to read, what questions to ask their children, and how to respond
to their children's answers. Thus, mothers and children were to progress through
the materials in planned stages, providing children with a series of tasks to accom-
plish before advancing to increasing levels of difficulty.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"assess the effectiveness of participation in the program on major outcomes rele- vant to program goals."
"This
study tested the hypothesis that participation in HIPPY has a positive impact on
young children's cognitive skills, standardized achievement, and adaptation to the
classroom, over an above any effect of a high-quality preschool program.[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"The HIPPY program participating in this study was situated in a large city in
New York State. The HIPPY program became operational in 1989 as a parent
involvement component of the city's public school Early Childhood Center. The
Center provided an enriched, high-quality early childhood education setting for
prekindergarten and kindergarten children, many of whom were from low-income
families with limited English proficiency and from ethnic minorities.[¬e]"']

int_objec_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"The effectiveness of the Home Instruction Program for Preschool Youngsters (HIPPY)---a two-year, free, home-based, family-oriented, early childhood educa- tion intervention--was assessed in a longitudinal, two cohort, randomized exper- imental evaluation."
"Outcomes included assessments of children's cogni-
tive skills, adaptation to the classroom, and standardized achievement at the end
of the two-year program, and classroom adaptation and standardized achievement
one year later.[¬e]"']

int_training_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"In order to enhance the home learning environment and develop each mother's ability to support her child's lifelong learning, Lombard designed the program for mothers to deliver the HIPPY lessons to their children (as opposed to a home vis- itor working with the children directly). By learning how to teach their child and by having successful teaching experiences, the goal was for HIPPY mothers to gain confidence, interest, and skills to help their children succeed academically even after the completion of the two year HIPPY program. Over the course of the program, mothers received a series of books written spe- cifically for the HIPPY program along with activity packets."
"These activities ranged from a series of questions the
mother was to ask the child, along with possible responses; connect the dot activi-
ties; identifying the appropriate object from a printed matrix (e.g., find the girl
with the hat from a matrix of boys and girls with and without hats); and coloring
activities. The HIPPY activities were structured like a detailed lesson plan to guide
mothers in what to read, what questions to ask their children, and how to respond
to their children's answers.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"Prior to working with her child on the HIPPY lessons, Lombard designed the
model such that mothers first were presented the lesson by the paraprofessional
during the home visit. During the role-playing session, mothers were to take the
role of the child and the paraprofessional took the role of the parent. Thus, mothers
learned to use the materials through role playing each week's lessons with the
home visitor. Role playing was chosen by Lombard so that mothers could learn in
a relaxed, playful, and nonthreatening atmosphere. In that way, the home visitor
functions as a modeler of teaching techniques.[¬e]"']

some families moved away before the program began. Table 1 presents a descrip-
tion of the sample by group and cohort.
As can be seen from Table 1, about two-thirds of the families were from ethnic
minorities, primarily African American and Latino backgrounds. One third of the
families reported that public assistance was their primary source of income. Fam-
ilies were evenly divided between single parents and couples. As can be seen, a
substantial proportion (28% to 41%) of the families had educations beyond high
school. Despite this educational advantage, many families did not speak English as
their primary language (n = 63, 34.6%).
Procedures
Baseline Data Collection. Baseline data were collected during individualized
home visits conducted by trained research assistants not associated with the
HIPPY program. For Cohort I, baseline data were collected in February 1991
(rather than in the Fall), because of delays in the beginning of the HIPPY program.
Cohort II baseline took place at the beginning of the next school year (September
1991), which coincided with the beginning of their first year of the HIPPY pro-

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The parent training program was identical to that published
by Barkley (1987) and was oﬀered to parents in a group format
over 10 weekly sessions beginning in October of each year.
Following these weekly sessions, monthly booster sessions were
oﬀered to these parents from January to May of the kin-
dergarten year. All parent training groups were conducted by
the same child psychologist who was trained by the ﬁrst author
and who had 5 years experience in this treatment program.
The parent training program is comprised of sessions teaching
parents: (1) the causes ofdeﬁant behavior; (2) positive attending
skills and praising; (3) attending to child compliance and
improving parental command eﬀectiveness; (4) rewarding
children for nondisruptive behavior; (5) setting up a home
token system; (6) time out and response cost (ﬁnes in token
system); (7) managing children in public places with think
aloud-think ahead strategies.[¬e]"']

dren received a relatively thorough psychological and
psychiatric evaluation, after which they participated in
several diﬀerent treatment programs involving behav-
ioral, psychosocial, and academic interventions aimed
at reducing their risk for negative behavioral, emotional,
academic, and social outcomes.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"Results showed
that parent training produced no signiﬁcant treatment eﬀects, probably owing largely to
poor attendance.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"A comparison was then made of those parents who did not attend parent training (Nl25) with parents who did attend at least one training session (Nl51) on measures of child and parent characteristics assessed at the initial evaluation of these children."
"Results indi-
cated that the nonattendees did not diﬀer signiﬁcantly
from the attendees in the age of the children (4.7 vs. 4.8
yrs.), the children’s IQ (94 vs. 97), the mothers’ ages (28
vs. 29 yrs.), the fathers’ ages (32 vs. 32 yrs.), or the fathers’[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"social class (43 vs. 40 on Hollingshead). Nor were any
diﬀerences found on either teacher CBCL ratings of
attention problems or aggression, or on measures of
parental marital satisfaction, as assessed by the Locke-
Wallace Marital Adjustment Test (Locke & Wallace,
1959; see also Barkley, 1981), or parental depression and
general parental psychopathology, as assessed by the
Symptom Checklist 90 Revised (Derogatis, 1986). The
families who failed to attend training had both mothers
and fathers who were signiﬁcantly less educated than
those families who did attend training [mothers: 12 vs. 13
yrs., t (74)lk2.15, pl.035; fathers: 11.5 vs. 12.6 yrs.,
t (52)lk2.55, pl.014]. Surprisingly, the children of
the nonattendees were rated as being signiﬁcantly less
inattentive and aggressive by their parents on the CBCL
than were the children of families who attended train-
ing [CBCL Attention T-score: 57.4 vs. 63.8, t(74)l
k3.18, pl.002; CBCL Aggression T-score: 63.9 vs.
69.2, t(74)lk2.37, pl.021]. All of this suggests that
although nonattendees may have been less educated,
these parents may also have had less incentive to attend
training given that their children were viewed by them as
signiﬁcantly less problematic in their behavior than were
the children of families who attended parent training.[¬e]"']
int_fidel_info: Though this includes the treatment group that combined parent training and classroom treatment

int_desc_ht:
['Page 89:
[¬s]"The district reading specialist, kindergarten teachers, and Title I aids
administered a screening instrument during kindergarten registration in April 2003
(Appendix E). The screening instrument was used to place children into program
and non-program status.
The independent variable (phonological awareness instruction) was
administered daily for 2 hours June 9 - July 4, 2003, to 93 children that scored
below 54 points on the screening instrument. Children received explicit
phonological awareness instruction from trained early childhood educators. The
program was designed to build on existing family literacy practices and to increase
phonological awareness skills including: word comparison, rhyming, syllable
segmentation, sentence segmentation, initial sounds, onsets/rimes segmentation and
blending, and phoneme manipulation, segmentation and blending. Parents were
invited to the program one day per week to receive training specific to home[¬e]"', 'Page 90:
[¬s]"interventions in phonological awareness (Appendix C). The parents were asked to
implement phonological awareness activities into the daily homework of their
child.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The purpose of this study was to determine if prekindergarten children who
participated in an explicit phonological-awareness training program, which
included their parents as teachers, entered kindergarten at a reading readiness level
higher than would have been expected had they not participated in the program.
An additional goal of this research was to demonstrate the utility of the regression
discontinuity design in program evaluation.[¬e]"']

base_diff_info: The study groups were decided on a threshold for scores in a schooling preparedness test.
comp_anal_ht:
['Page 38:
[¬s]"Prekindergarten children living in Logan, Utah, attended kindergarten
registration with their parent(s) or guardian(s) at the LCSD District Office during
April 2003. During the registration process, every child participated in the LCSD
Kindergarten Readiness Screening (Appendix E)."
"The LCSD Kindergarten
Readiness Screening was used to assign children to program or nonprogram status.
A cut score was established and the children who scored below the cut point on the
LCSD Kindergarten Readiness Screening (93 children) received treatment in the
program. Those children, who scored above the cut point on the LCSD
Kindergarten Readiness Screening (244 children) were placed in the comparison
group. This method of assignment, adherence to a cut score, was consistent with
the regression discontinuity (RD) design used in the study.[¬e]"']
comp_anal_info: The children lived in the catchment area for the same schools and received the same test, this was what was needed to qualify for the RDD.

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"The Mother–Child Education Program focuses on both the child and the child’s immediate
environment rather than reaching only the child. To promote the child’s overall development,
the mother, as the significant person in the child’s home context, is the key contact person."
"The
Mother–Child Education Program reaches children and parents just before the children start
formal school and has three main elements: cognitive training, a mother enrichment program,
and reproductive health and family planning."
"Cognitive Training Program[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"Mothers are supplied each week with 20–25 pages of work sheets that contain various daily
exercises to be used by the mother with the child in the above areas. Each week’s materials
contain various daily exercises to be used by the mother with the child and take about 15 to 20
minutes to complete. Pages assigned for each day of the week are marked to help mothers
keep track of the activities."
"In addition to the work sheets, eight picture storybooks (Alpöge 1995) are used for training in
listening comprehension, verbal description, vocabulary, question–answer activities, and
reasoning."
". Interactive shared book-reading activities are given particular emphasis because
the origins of emergent literacy are thought to be found in early mother–child interaction
during activities related to picture books and reading materials."
"Mother Enrichment Program[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"The topics of the Mother Enrichment Program included children’s health and nutrition,
cognitive, social, and physical development, creative play activities, and the importance of
play. Topics such as discipline, methods for changing negative behaviors, and other facets of
mother–child interaction and communication were also discussed. Group discussions focused
on expressing and listening to the feelings of the child and their acceptance. Generalizations
were then made to other human relations, including spousal relations. Some meetings were
also devoted to the mothers’ feelings about being a woman and a mother. Throughout the
program, the mothers were encouraged to develop a positive self-concept, as the group
discussions were oriented toward supporting the mothers in developing feelings of
competence, efficacy, and self-confidence."
"Reproductive Health and Family Planning
This component of the program aimed to enable mothers to understand their reproductive
system and to improve reproductive health. Topics such as healthy pregnancy, safe
motherhood, and methods of family planning were discussed."
"For 25 weeks, mothers came to group meetings held once a week at the adult education
centers located in each district of every province. In the first part of each meeting, that week’s
topic of the Mother Empowerment Program was discussed for an hour and a half. The
techniques of group dynamics were utilised to enable the mothers to provide their children[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"with greater support in their interactions. The second part of the meeting was devoted to
topics in Reproductive Health and Family Planning and lasted about 15 minutes.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 13:
[¬s]"To investigate the quality and frequency of the implementation of the Cognitive Training Program at home, observations were made at the beginning, middle, and end of the program. The Observation Schedule focused on the teaching experience of the mother with her child to assess the quality of the teaching process at home."
"The adequacy of teaching was assessed
with a 5-point scale with values from inadequate (1) to excellent (5). For the observation
scale, both interobserver reliability and internal consistency were assessed. A minimum
agreement of 75% was accepted among the observers to end the training. The internal
reliability score for the home observation scale was .72. Data from children were collected at
home and the data from the teachers were collected at school.[¬e]"', 'Page 18:
[¬s]"A comparison of home observations conducted at three different times to investigate how well
the mothers implement the cognitive development program revealed differences for the whole
group. An increase in the mean scores was observed over time. Mean scores = 3.66, 4.16, and
4.39. All paired t test comparisons were significant: first and second t(106) = 9.57, p = .000;
second and third t(106) = 5.18, p = .000; and first and third t(106) = 13.46, p = .000.[¬e]"']

comp_var_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The four groups were formed from 20 boys and 20 girls, ranging in age from 3
years 5 months to 4 years 5 months. The children had been assessed on Raven’s
Progressive Matrices, Reynell Comprehension and Expressive Language Scales and
the English Picture Vocabulary Test (EPVT). These 40 children were selected so that
each group member was closely matched on these measures to one member of each of
the other groups. The four groups were thus made up of 10 matched quartets. There
were no significant differences (t-test) between any pair of groups in the initial
assessments.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 44:
[¬s]"The rhyming activities focused on the child considering what rhymes
with selected words or supplying the missing rhyming word when presented with a rhyming
phrase. Sound identification activities included the presentation o f a series o f pictures of
familiar objects and asking the child to identify the one that begins with the selected sound,
or listening for a selected letter sound during storybook reading. Sound isolation activities
involved listening to a series o f words, or looking at familiar pictures, identifying the sound
that occurs at the beginning o f the words, and being able to select out a word or picture that
did not match the beginning sound o f the other words (see Appendix D)."
"The alphabetic principle, or letter activities were designed to give children
opportunities to explore and identify sound-letter relationships, as well as letter shapes and
names. Letter manipulatives were provided, as were alphabetic or rhyming books and a list of
suggested books, as these activities encourage exploration and learning o f letters (IRA &
NAEYC, 1998). The parents were also encouraged to read to their children every day and
were provided with a sample developmentally appropriate book and recommended book lists.[¬e]"', 'Page 45:
[¬s]"In addition, the
children all received activity bags and a book for their participation. The activity bags
contained letter magnets, crayons, activity folders, upper and lower-case letter flash cards,
and pipe cleaners for letter shaping.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 14:
[¬s]"Training parents to provide
instruction in letter sounds and letter identification, in addition to engaging in shared reading
activities, may allow them to further enhance their children's early literacy development.
These activities may provide a stronger foundation for formal reading instruction.[¬e]"', 'Page 43:
[¬s]"The activities and materials were designed to target early literacy skills as
well as address recommended developmentally appropriate practice standards.[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht: NA
int_training_ht:
['Page 42:
[¬s]"The training session occurred at the Head Start sites, and local libraries.
The session consisted of a brief, carefully scripted training (up to 2 hours) in various
activities to support preliteracy development, including letter recognition, letter sounds,
rhyming, and beginning letter sounds. The training was developed based on Head Start
guidelines for designing parenting education. For example, three characteristics o f the[¬e]"', 'Page 43:
[¬s]"potential participants were considered: culture, gender, and age. Therefore, training
materials, teaching strategies, and terms were carefully selected to ensure they were sensitive
to the specific characteristics o f families within the program. The trainer considered adult
learning styles in the development o f the training, as some parents/caregivers may express
themselves and learn in ways that might require some alternative methods for learning the
literacy activities. For example, the participants were provided with the opportunity to
engage in hands-on practice with the literacy activities, as well as demonstration,
observation, and discussion o f the activities. In addition, the training was designed from a
strengths perspective, in order to recognize the skills and knowledge parents/caregivers may
already have had about literacy activities and to build on that background (DHHS, n.d.). For
example, parents were asked to discuss any previous experience with similar activities and to
elaborate upon any literacy activities they already used in the home."
"During parent training, an emphasis was
placed on keeping the parent-child learning time fun. The activities involved using such
familiar child materials as pipe cleaners, magnetic letters, picture cards, and crayons. In
addition, parents were encouraged to look for opportunities for learning within child-initiated[¬e]"', 'Page 44:
[¬s]"activities, and the activities were designed to be game-like and entertaining (Bredekamp &
Copple, 1997).[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"Tutor\xad
ing sessions were structured and used rich
reading materials. Paired reading is a sim\xad
ple method for non-professionals which
can be adapted and takes into considera\xad
tion the interests of the pupils. This
technique is divided in two stages: simul\xad
taneous reading and independent reading.
Before beginning the reading session, the
child chooses a book and discusses the[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"story or the subject with his/her parent.
Then, the child and the parent begin with
simultaneous reading. During this phase,
the child reads out loud at the same time
as the parent. The parent corrects the child's
mistakes only by modeling. During the
independent reading phase, the child gives
a signal to the parent to indicate that he/she
is ready to read alone. The parent praises
the child for taking this initiative and
encourages him/her regularly. When the
child makes a mistakes, the parent corrects
him/her, making sure that the child repeats
exactly the same thing, then starts reading
out loud with the child again.[¬e]"']

int_training_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"Training of the tutors by a spe\xad
cialist. Two research assistants who were
completing their final year in a remedial
teaching program acted as reading spe\xad
cialists for this research project. They
received thorough instructions on how to
train parents on using the paired reading
technique and on how to supervise them.
The assistants' training included learning
the principles and features of the paired
reading technique, practical training ses\xad
sions to allow them to experiment the
technique and integrate its particularities,
and assessment of the tutors and tutees.
Three two hour theoretical training ses\xad
sions and four or live practical training
sessions with a child allowed the assistants
to master perfectly all the elements of the
program. In order to evaluate their com\xad
petencies, a checklist inspired by Bushnell
et al. (1982) was used. The two assistants
both had scores of 5 out of 5 on all items
of the list. The assistants were supervised
throughout the entire year to ensure that
they maintained a proper level of know l\xad
edge of the paired reading technique.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 8:
[¬s]"Consistency and intensity of the program. Tutoring is intensive and con\xad sistent. During each reading activity, the child chose by himself/herself the mater\xad ial before beginning reading with one of his/her parents. The length of the reading session was at least five minutes each day. five days a w eek. The parents were instruct\xad ed not go beyond 15 minutes per day unless the child slated that he/she wanted to con\xad tinue. The location chosen for reading varied from one child to another (bedroom, kitchen table, living room), but had to be a calm and comfortable location. Parents were instructed to turn off the television or the radio. It was also suggested to parents and children to read in close physical prox\xad imity to make the experience more intimate and enjoyable. 5) Quality of the material. Good quality materials were used with all sub\xad jects to ensure a certain uniformity and enjoyment of reading. Since the reading materials available to each child at home were different, we gave a standard mater\xad ial package to all participants. This package included 50 Hash cards (26 letters, 16 con\xad sonant-vowel syllables and 8 consonant-vow el-consonant syllables) and 32 small first grade books from a popular series of child literature in Quebec. The flash cards were used for letter reading and syllable recognition activities, while the small books were introduced to practice reading with prose-like materials. The sto\xad ries included in the books were adapted to the reading level of the pupils and followed the progression of materials received in school. The children received two or three books at each tutoring session. These books contained illustrations and were interest\xad ing from the children’s perspective. They were adapted to the level of the reading abilities of the child and parent."
"Assessment of the tutors on a reg\xad
ular basis. To verify the frequency of
reading sessions, a calendar was provided
to parents and their children. Each reading
session was recorded by putting an X or
the number of a book in the space corre\xad
sponding to a particular day on the calendar
following each session. Moreover, a short
reading activity was proposed to parents
and children for each day of the calendar.
Parents could do this activity with their
child in an informal way in order to have
fun w hile reading. Also, a booklet was pro\xad[¬e]"', 'Page 9:

they may have had in-between visits. More\xad
over. the goal of the home visits was to
assess compliance with the paired reading
technique and correct the parents to ensure
they achieved an acceptable level of under\xad
standing. During these visits, the parent
and the child practiced reading while the
assistant observed them. Afterwards, the

on positive aspects, then by discussing

With a checklist inspired by Bushnell et
al. (1982), the parents had to obtain a score

evaluated and corrected immediately until

all the criteria that applied to simultaneous

training, most visits lasted about an hour,
and in some cases even required two hours.
After one or two visits, the assistants rarely

int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"Fathers Supporting\nSuccess in Preschoolers: A Community Parent Education Program[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"Intervention Condition—The FSSP program is an 8-week, 90-min-per-week, group-
based intervention held during the late afternoon hours at the child’s Head Start center.
Within the context of shared book reading, DR forms the foundation of the FSSP program,
with common elements of BPT integrated and generalized through a coping–modeling–
problem-solving subgroup approach. Videotaped vignettes of father–child reading[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"interactions were used to provide opportunities for small- and large-group discussions.
Groups ranged in size from six to 12 fathers, with small subgroups consisting of three or
four fathers. Fathers had access to age-appropriate books through the participating Head
Start site to complete homework and practice implementation of DR at home.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"Engaging fathers and improving their parenting and, in turn, outcomes for their children in
preventive/promotion-focused parenting interventions has been a notable, but understudied,
challenge in the field. This study evaluated the effects of a novel intervention, Fathers Supporting
Success in Preschoolers: A Community Parent Education Program, which focuses on integrating
behavioral parent training with shared book reading (i.e., Dialogic Reading) using key conceptual
models (i.e., common elements, deployment model, task shifting) to engage and improve father
(i.e., male guardians) and child outcomes.[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"Anil ChackoiD,
Department of Applied Psychology, New York University
Gregory A. Fabiano,
Counseling, School, and Educational Psychology, University at Buffalo
Greta L. Doctoroff, and
Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology, Yeshiva University
Beverly Fortson
Division of Violence Prevention, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention[¬e]"']
int_training_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"This study evaluated the effects of a novel intervention, Fathers Supporting
Success in Preschoolers: A Community Parent Education Program, which focuses on integrating
behavioral parent training with shared book reading (i.e., Dialogic Reading) using key conceptual
models (i.e., common elements, deployment model, task shifting) to engage and improve father
(i.e., male guardians) and child outcomes.[¬e]"', 'Page 10:
[¬s]"Initial training was provided by the FSSP developers to all FSSP parent facilitators during
three 2-hr in-person trainings that occurred weekly for 3 consecutive weeks. The focus of the
training was on the content and process of the FSSP, as well as understanding and
implementing DR and common elements of BPT. Training methods included reading of the
FSSP manual, didactic lecture, modeling, roleplay, and completion of homework
assignments. Based on posttraining evaluations, which included a written test and role-plays
of key processes within FSSP, further training was conducted for two of the seven FSSP
parent facilitators who did not attain competency after the initial training. These two
facilitators were provided additional training (i.e., additional 2 hr of training) to achieve
initial levels of competence. Child-group facilitators completed a 1-hr training focused on
group-management procedures[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 10:
[¬s]"All FSSP sessions were videotaped, and
these fidelity assessments were used by research staff to assess for treatment fidelity. Fidelity
data demonstrated that FSSP facilitators implemented the FSSP intervention with an average
rate of fidelity equaling 88%. In addition, senior research staff held brief (30–45 min)
weekly group supervision with each facilitator team to review key issues gleaned from the
videotaped fidelity assessments, discuss content and process of the groups, and discuss
challenges in implementation or issues that arose during the group sessions. Videotaped
FSSP sessions also served as opportunities for additional adaptive training. Specifically,
additional training was provided when fidelity ratings for FSSP facilitator pairs fell below
80% for two consecutive FSSP sessions.[¬e]"', 'Page 11:
[¬s]"Additional remedial training was provided for two FSSP
facilitator pairs across the duration of the study due to low levels of adherence (< 80%).
Fidelity was not conducted for the child groups.[¬e]"']

int_training_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"Parents of
children in the intervention group, however, were
trained to use the Child Behavior and Language
Assessment (CBLA). Parents were taught to complete
weekly assessments of their children by recording
positive and negative events and to submit monthly
summaries to project staﬀ. At the beginning of the
intervention, parents completed the Problem Identi-
ﬁcation Checklist in the CBLA. The parent rated
their child on health, motor skills, behavior, and
receptive and expressive language items as 1=need
professional help, 2=need some help with this
problem, 3=watch carefully and make notes, and
4=no problem. The parent then selected activities in
the Activities section of the CBLA and used the
Problems Analysis Log to keep track of whether the
activities helped. As parents conducted the assess-
ment and deﬁned the problems, parent denial of
developmental issues did not become an issue.
In addition to using the CBLA, parents of the
children in the intervention group participated in an
ongoing ‘‘parent–professional dyad’’ relationship
with project staﬀ.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:

[¬s]"First the implementation of the intervention activities was examined. At posttest, all children in the
three intervention conditions reported that their parents had engaged them in playing the number
board game or working on the exercise books assigned by us. Meanwhile, 22 out of 23 parents in the
game with parent training group reported the frequency with which they introduced various types of
numeracy-related content when playing the number board game with their children during the
intervention period. Of various types of numeracy-related content, addition was introduced the most
frequently during parent–child number board game playing (M = 4.55, SD = 0.60), followed by
counting aloud the number of steps the token moved (M = 4.33, SD = 0.66), reading of numerals
(M = 4.18, SD = 1.26), comparison of numerical magnitude (M = 3.77, SD = 1.34), and recitation of
number sequence (M = 3.73, SD = 1.32)[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"In the dialogic reading program, each child was provided with a total of 8 books. Hints for prompt questions and recall prompts were added in each book. One book and the pictures[¬e]"', 'Page 9:\n[¬s]"for the corresponding book were distributed each week by teachers. Parents were encouraged to read each book twice in a week for 15 minutes each time with their children. The first book, a dialogic reading guideline, a calendar checklist, and pictures for that book were initially given to the parents. The parents were trained individually through a 20-minute training session by phone before the reading intervention started. They were trained to use special strategies and the materials given to encourage their children to be active storytellers in parent-child reading. The fundamental reading technique in dialogic reading is the PEER sequence in parent-child reading. The parent prompts the child to say something about the storybook, evaluates the child\x92s response, expands the child\x92s responses by rephrasing and adding information, and repeats the prompt to ensure the child has learned from the expansion.[¬e]"']

int_part_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"This study investigates the effects of parent–child shared book reading and metalinguistic training on the
language and literacy skills of 148 kindergartners in Hong Kong.[¬e]"', 'Page 1:
[¬s]"A specific technique of parent–child reading developed by
Whitehurst and colleagues called dialogic reading (DR) involves
high levels of interaction between parents and children (White-
hurst et al., 1988).[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"The fundamental reading technique in DR is
the PEER sequence in parent–child reading: The parent prompts
the child to say something about the storybook, evaluates the
child’s response, expands the child’s responses by rephrasing and
adding information, and repeats the prompt to ensure the child has
learned from the expansion. There are five types of prompts,
including completion, recall, open-ended, wh-, and distancing
prompts, used in the DR technique.[¬e]"']

cation during shared book reading, and increases in
children’s performance on structured vocabulary mea-
sures.[¬e]"']

int_name_info: There is no official name given to the intervention
int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"The intervention procedure in respect of the two school-based groups
(A and B) was one devised by the author in 1972 and now in operation in eight
Renfrewshire schools at the request of head teachers.
The experimental preschool children and their mothers were asked to attend
the school each Thursday at 3 p.m. from February, 1974, to June, 1974. While
the children played under the supervision of auxiliaries, the mothers selected a
book to read at home to the children from a supply provided by the primary
adviser and the county library. The mothers then had tea with the three infants’
teachers who had volunteered for the project, in an effort to enhance relations
between mothers and teachers. After tea, mothers met in groups chaired by
teachers. Three mothers had two children involved and each teacher chaired a
random group of 12 mothers.
In addition to story books, each mother was
provided each week with a typed unit of a programme devised by the child
guidance department for mothers to administer at home. This programme
prescribes materials likely to be available in all homes and deals with general
vocabulary, simple number and relationships of time, space and size. Mothers
were asked to spend a total of 30 minutes a day on the book and programme.
At the group meetings each mother was asked to say how she fared with the
child during the previous week and received suggestions from the other members.
Discussion at group meetings often ranged over wider aspects of education
and child rearing and mothers appeared to be sufficiently reinforced by these
meetings to persist in the programme.[¬e]"']

"children of exposure to a four-month programme administered by mothers at

expected that significant cognitive and linguistic gains would accrue from
participation in the programme.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"The programs used a parent coaching strategy, following classic
principles from Bandura’s social learning theory and Vygotsky’s
sociocultural theory."
"All three parent coaching interventions were structured
within thrice-weekly home visits for a total of 12 weeks. The first
two visits of the week lasted for 45 min each. In these sessions, the
teacher/parent coach demonstrated the activities with the child for
20 min, then turned over the session to the parent for the next 20
min. The remaining 5 min were used for feedback and discussion
with the parent. The third follow-up visit lasted for 25 min and was
mostly parent-led. Parents were constantly encouraged to continue
carrying out the activities with their children in their free time."
"In the numeracy parent coaching inter-
vention, families were given two number card packs with 44 cards
each. The first card pack introduced numerals and quantities rang-
ing from 1 to 10, and the second card pack introduced numerals
and quantities ranging from 1 to 20. On each card, a set of animals
was printed on one side and the numeral representing the number
of animals was printed on the other side. In the parent coaching
sessions, teachers modeled number card games that involved the
following numeracy components: (a) rote counting from 1 to 20
(or beyond, depending on children’s abilities), (b) numeral iden-
tification using the number flashcards, (c) one-to-one counting of
the sets of animals printed on the number cards, (d) identification
of a missing number in a sequence, (e) numerical magnitude and
quantity comparison, and (f) simple addition.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"Overall, the present study aimed to evaluate whether or not a
parent coaching design could effectively boost skills of young
Filipino children from low- to middle-income families. Program
effects were expected to be relatively specific according to pro-
gram content: that numeracy training would especially benefit
children’s numeracy skills, that dialogic reading training would
especially benefit children’s vocabulary skills, and that early lit-
eracy skills training would especially benefit children’s early lit-
eracy skills[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"Formal
partnerships with the communities were secured by a collaborating
nongovernment organization (NGO). I[¬e]"']
int_training_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"The programs used a parent coaching strategy, following classic principles from Bandura’s social learning theory and Vygotsky’s sociocultural theory. Modeling, practice, and feedback were given to help parents learn from the parent coaches (Bandura & Walters, 1963) on how to provide higher-quality scaffolding during nu- meracy, language, or literacy-related interactions with their chil- dren, so as to promote children’s cognitive development (Vy- gotsky, 1978)."
"All three parent coaching interventions were structured
within thrice-weekly home visits for a total of 12 weeks. The first
two visits of the week lasted for 45 min each. In these sessions, the
teacher/parent coach demonstrated the activities with the child for
20 min, then turned over the session to the parent for the next 20
min. The remaining 5 min were used for feedback and discussion
with the parent.[¬e]"']
int_approach_ht: NA
int_fidel_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"Teacher records. Teachers submitted checklists and narrative reports about individual children’s progress. Checklists were ex- plicitly aligned with program content, for example, evaluations of children’s letter recognition ability were arranged in the letter order prescribed in the program, numeracy card games were listed according to the numeracy skills that they were designed to tap, and children’s ability to respond to dialogic reading prompts were documented according to each type of CROWD prompt. Teachers completed planning templates with specific CROWD prompts that were given about every storybook in the program and word lists that were used for phonological awareness games."
". Narrative re-
ports described children’s milestones per week of program imple-
mentation (e.g., child can identify numbers 1–2, child can identify
letters U and K, and child is more talkative during dialogic
reading). This collection of reports was submitted every week and
was reviewed by the team leaders and Philip Reyes for complete-
ness and compliance. Furthermore, an overall report about every
child was submitted at the end of program implementation."
"Team-level monitoring and documentation. On the team
level, teachers met every day for morning focus group discussions
to discuss problems encountered in the previous sessions and
possible interventions for them. Common problems reported were
participant compliance with their agreed-upon time of parent coach-
ing, motivating parents to use positive reinforcement on their children
and to become more confident to take over the coaching session, and
sustaining a high level of parent participation throughout program
implementation. Solutions implemented were setting clear guidelines[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"and considerations for attendance, modeling positive reinforcement,
gradually increasing the proportion of parent-led session time until
parents could facilitate activities for the prescribed 20 min, and
providing feedback about developmentally appropriate practices dur-
ing the allotted time for parent–teacher discussions. Furthermore,
team leaders discussed program content to be covered for the day and
conducted refresher training sessions for specific activities that teach-
ers reported having difficulties with. Team-level documentation on
problems encountered was reviewed weekly to monitor whether or
not problems were adequately resolved. Each team also submitted
weekly photo documentation from assigned teachers that showed
parents implementing the program activities."
"Centralized monitoring. On a centralized level, Philip Reyes
was on-site during program implementation to address immediate
concerns from individual teachers and team leaders, convened all
teachers weekly to discuss overall program implementation issues,
and received referral sheets to personally address specific issues
observed with certain teachers and families. Finally, the rest of the
research team was consulted about program implementation de-
tails and clarifications via e-mail as such issues arose.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"Three levels of monitoring were used to ensure treatment fidel-
ity: (a) individual teacher records, (b) team-level monitoring and
documentation, and (c) centralized on-site monitoring by Philip
Reyes. On the individual teacher level, parents signed forms to
confirm receipt of program materials provided and to confirm the
start and end time of every coaching session. Based on individual
time logs of 426 families that received parent coaching and lists of
participants who dropped out of the intervention, 88% of the 482
beneficiary families completed all 36 sessions, 4% dropped out
prior to program implementation, and 8% dropped out within the
12-week program implementation, with 3 to 27 sessions com-
pleted. Overall program dropout rates were not significantly dif-
ferent between groups based on a chi-square test of indepen-
dence—13%, 10%, and 14% within the numeracy, DR, and EL
groups, respectively. As summarized in Figure 2, some variability
was observed in drop out patterns by teacher assignment. Families[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"Teacher evaluation. The team leaders and Philip Reyes col-
laborated on teacher evaluation reports at the end of the program,
based on on-site observations and teacher reports. Each teacher
was evaluated on 20 items on a 5-point rating scale (0 ⫽ unsatis-
factory, 1 ⫽ below average, 2 ⫽ average, 3 ⫽ good, and 4 ⫽ very
good). Items were related to the use of effective teaching strategies
and teaching materials, communication with children and parents,
quality of session preparation and documentation, and time man-
agement skills. The mean teacher evaluation score was 3.21 (SD ⫽
0.28, range ⫽ 2.6–4.0).[¬e]"']

[¬s]"Notes on Pretest Equivalence Between Groups and

Because random assignment was performed irrespective of chil-
dren’s pretest performance, pretest group equivalence in children’s
age and measures in the numeracy, language, and literacy domains
was evaluated using one-way analyses of variance (ANOVAs) on
the full pretest sample (N⫽ 673) and on remaining participants at
posttest (N⫽ 578). No systematic group differences were found in"
"any of the measures. Chi-square tests of independence revealed no
significant differences in the distributions of children’s gender and
preschool attendance at pretest or posttest. Furthermore, one-way
ANOVAs to evaluate possible group differences in the socioeco-
nomic status (SES) factor score and total time of parental involve-
ment in program activities outside of coaching hours were not
significant.
Systematic test-order effects were evaluated using two-way
ANOVAs that specified group and block order as independent
variables. No differences by Group ⫻ Block Order were found in
any of the outcome measures at the pretest and posttest periods.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"This represented an overall"
"pretest-posttest attrition rate of 14%, with no group demonstrating
a significantly higher attrition rate compared to other groups:
numeracy (14%), DR (12%), EL (17%), and control (14%). At
posttest, children’s mean age was 55.74 months (SD ⫽ 10.08,
range ⫽ 37–75 months) and gender distribution remained the same
(53% boys)[¬e]"', 'Page 9:

[¬s]"Effects of gender, age, and preschool attendance. Gender,
age, and preschool attendance were added as additional covariates
in the ANCOVA analyses. In the regression equivalents of these
models, boys scored better on the book vocabulary measure than
girls (␤⫽⫺.08, p ⫽ .013), whereas girls scored better in the object
counting (␤⫽ .07, p ⫽ .027) and syllable deletion (␤⫽ .09, p ⫽
.021) tasks. No other gender-related effects were noted in other
measures. Age was positively and significantly associated with
higher scores in all outcome measures (␤s ⫽ .13–.38). Finally,
preschool attendance was positively and significantly associated
with higher scores in all outcome measures except syllable match-
ing and print/word awareness (significant ␤s ⫽ .08–.16). How-
ever, the associations of preschool attendance with missing num-
ber and syllable deletion disappeared when unresolved covariate
interactions were accounted for.[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"As a first step, ANCOVA models were
specified with group as the independent variable, posttest perfor-
mance as the dependent variable, and the pretest score on the
outcome measure being tested as a covariate (pretest-only model).[¬e]"']

clust_anal_info: I am not sure about this. Data are clustered according to the family. However, the 1st research question (which is the one we are interested into  it investigates the effect of intervention of numeracy scores) is answered using two ANCOVA (two models, the latter having more covariates than the former). In this case, I would say that clustering is not accounted for. A hierarchical model is used later, to investigate the moderating effect of SES, but we are not interested in this.

int_desc_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"Over the first 10 weeks of the dialogic reading program, a new picture storybook was introduced and given to each family every week. The storybooks were written by Filipino authors and were published locally in a bilingual English-Filipino or English-Cebuano format"
"In this program, teach-
ers modeled key principles of dialogic reading such as the PEER
sequence and CROWD prompts for the parents to follow, with the
objective of transitioning from relatively straightforward book
reading to the child answering prompts and taking the lead in
storytelling (Arnold et al., 1994). The last 2 weeks were used to
reintroduce the 10 storybooks used in the program.[¬e]"']

home numeracy and literacy environments in Cebu City, Philippines"
"Children in the numeracy group manifested improved basic and complex numeracy
skills, and children in the dialogic reading group demonstrated gains in vocabulary knowledge for words
in the books that they were exposed to, as well as print and word awareness, to a limited degree. Children
in the early literacy skills training group had improved letter name knowledge, phonological awareness,
and print and word awareness skills.[¬e]"', 'Page 1:
[¬s]"The current study evaluates the efficacy of parent coaching programs designed to enrich
home numeracy and literacy environments in Cebu City, Philippines. A total of 673 families with 3- to

training, and control groups.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"Teacher records. Teachers submitted checklists and narrative reports about individual children’s progress. Checklists were ex- plicitly aligned with program content, for example, evaluations of children’s letter recognition ability were arranged in the letter order prescribed in the program, numeracy card games were listed according to the numeracy skills that they were designed to tap, and children’s ability to respond to dialogic reading prompts were documented according to each type of CROWD prompt. Teachers completed planning templates with specific CROWD prompts that were given about every storybook in the program and word lists that were used for phonological awareness games. Narrative re- ports described children’s milestones per week of program imple- mentation (e.g., child can identify numbers 1–2, child can identify letters U and K, and child is more talkative during dialogic reading). This collection of reports was submitted every week and was reviewed by the team leaders and Philip Reyes for complete- ness and compliance. Furthermore, an overall report about every child was submitted at the end of program implementation."
"Team-level monitoring and documentation. On the team
level, teachers met every day for morning focus group discussions
to discuss problems encountered in the previous sessions and
possible interventions for them. Common problems reported were
participant compliance with their agreed-upon time of parent coach-
ing, motivating parents to use positive reinforcement on their children
and to become more confident to take over the coaching session, and
sustaining a high level of parent participation throughout program
implementation. Solutions implemented were setting clear guidelines[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"and considerations for attendance, modeling positive reinforcement,
gradually increasing the proportion of parent-led session time until
parents could facilitate activities for the prescribed 20 min, and
providing feedback about developmentally appropriate practices dur-
ing the allotted time for parent–teacher discussions. Furthermore,
team leaders discussed program content to be covered for the day and
conducted refresher training sessions for specific activities that teach-
ers reported having difficulties with. Team-level documentation on
problems encountered was reviewed weekly to monitor whether or
not problems were adequately resolved. Each team also submitted
weekly photo documentation from assigned teachers that showed
parents implementing the program activities.
Centralized monitoring. On a centralized level, Philip Reyes
was on-site during program implementation to address immediate
concerns from individual teachers and team leaders, convened all
teachers weekly to discuss overall program implementation issues,
and received referral sheets to personally address specific issues
observed with certain teachers and families. Finally, the rest of the
research team was consulted about program implementation de-
tails and clarifications via e-mail as such issues arose.[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"Over the course of the intervention,
teachers kept weekly records of parent-reported time spent doing
coaching activities outside of the teacher’s regular visits. Teacher
records from 44 out of 46 teachers (n ⫽ 426 children) were
retrieved. To create an overall index of parental involvement, the
sum of parent-reported minutes was divided by the total number of
weeks that the family participated in the parent coaching program.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"Three levels of monitoring were used to ensure treatment fidel- ity: (a) individual teacher records, (b) team-level monitoring and documentation, and (c) centralized on-site monitoring by Philip Reyes."
"Based on individual
time logs of 426 families that received parent coaching and lists of
participants who dropped out of the intervention, 88% of the 482
beneficiary families completed all 36 sessions, 4% dropped out
prior to program implementation, and 8% dropped out within the
12-week program implementation, with 3 to 27 sessions com-
pleted. Overall program dropout rates were not significantly dif-
ferent between groups based on a chi-square test of indepen-
dence—13%, 10%, and 14% within the numeracy, DR, and EL
groups, respectively. A[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"Teacher evaluation. The team leaders and Philip Reyes col-
laborated on teacher evaluation reports at the end of the program,
based on on-site observations and teacher reports. Each teacher
was evaluated on 20 items on a 5-point rating scale (0 ⫽ unsatis-
factory, 1 ⫽ below average, 2 ⫽ average, 3 ⫽ good, and 4 ⫽ very
good). Items were related to the use of effective teaching strategies
and teaching materials, communication with children and parents,
quality of session preparation and documentation, and time man-
agement skills. The mean teacher evaluation score was 3.21 (SD ⫽
0.28, range ⫽ 2.6–4.0).[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"The early literacy skills train-
ing program comprised six activities modeled by the teachers and
facilitated by the parents: (a) singing the alphabet song; (b) letter
name and sound recognition games using letter flashcards; (c)
phonological awareness games including syllable matching, sylla-
ble clapping, and syllable deletion; (d) speeded naming of pictures
and letters; (e) book reading with print and word awareness
prompts; and (f) a shared writing task. The book reading activity
used the same set of books from the DR program; however, the
teachers did not model dialogic reading techniques in this condi-
tion. Instead, teachers modeled prompts for children to pay atten-
tion to book handling behaviors and features of text.[¬e]"']

int_training_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"A total of 55 Cebuano-
speaking teachers with undergraduate degrees in education were
hired by the NGO to administer the intervention. All teachers were
trained in the three parent coaching interventions. In this imple-
mentation of the program, 45 teachers were randomly assigned to
a block of 10 to 11 families that lived in relative proximity to one
another. Because teacher assignment was contingent on location,
some teachers were occasionally assigned to implement one type
of intervention more than others. Nevertheless, all teachers were
assigned at least one family per type of intervention (see Figure 1).
Teachers were divided into two batches and received a 1-day
training seminar each by Katrina May Dulay on the DR and EL
interventions. After this, a field test was conducted and was video
recorded with selected teachers. The recordings were then shown
and discussed in a follow-up meeting with the teachers. Over the
following 2 weeks, the teachers received 2 weeks’ training led by[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"Philip Reyes. This covered the numeracy program, the use of the
number cards, and role-playing. The teachers were then sent for
further field training for one month. Teachers visited previous
NGO beneficiaries in pairs to acquire experience in conducting all
three intervention programs.[¬e]"']

['Page 7:
[¬s]"Team-level monitoring and documentation. On the team
level, teachers met every day for morning focus group discussions
to discuss problems encountered in the previous sessions and
possible interventions for them. Common problems reported were
participant compliance with their agreed-upon time of parent coach-
ing, motivating parents to use positive reinforcement on their children
and to become more confident to take over the coaching session, and
sustaining a high level of parent participation throughout program
implementation. Solutions implemented were setting clear guidelines[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"and considerations for attendance, modeling positive reinforcement,
gradually increasing the proportion of parent-led session time until
parents could facilitate activities for the prescribed 20 min, and
providing feedback about developmentally appropriate practices dur-
ing the allotted time for parent–teacher discussions. Furthermore,
team leaders discussed program content to be covered for the day and
conducted refresher training sessions for specific activities that teach-
ers reported having difficulties with. Team-level documentation on
problems encountered was reviewed weekly to monitor whether or
not problems were adequately resolved. Each team also submitted
weekly photo documentation from assigned teachers that showed
parents implementing the program activities.
Centralized monitoring. On a centralized level, Philip Reyes
was on-site during program implementation to address immediate
concerns from individual teachers and team leaders, convened all
teachers weekly to discuss overall program implementation issues,
and received referral sheets to personally address specific issues
observed with certain teachers and families. Finally, the rest of the
research team was consulted about program implementation de-
tails and clarifications via e-mail as such issues arose."
"Teacher evaluation. The team leaders and Philip Reyes col-
laborated on teacher evaluation reports at the end of the program,
based on on-site observations and teacher reports. Each teacher
was evaluated on 20 items on a 5-point rating scale (0 ⫽ unsatis-
factory, 1 ⫽ below average, 2 ⫽ average, 3 ⫽ good, and 4 ⫽ very
good). Items were related to the use of effective teaching strategies
and teaching materials, communication with children and parents,
quality of session preparation and documentation, and time man-
agement skills. The mean teacher evaluation score was 3.21 (SD ⫽
0.28, range ⫽ 2.6–4.0).[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"Three levels of monitoring were used to ensure treatment fidel- ity: (a) individual teacher records, (b) team-level monitoring and documentation, and (c) centralized on-site monitoring by Philip Reyes. On the individual teacher level, parents signed forms to confirm receipt of program materials provided and to confirm the start and end time of every coaching session. Based on individual time logs of 426 families that received parent coaching and lists of participants who dropped out of the intervention, 88% of the 482 beneficiary families completed all 36 sessions, 4% dropped out prior to program implementation, and 8% dropped out within the 12-week program implementation, with 3 to 27 sessions com- pleted. Overall program dropout rates were not significantly dif- ferent between groups based on a chi-square test of indepen- dence—13%, 10%, and 14% within the numeracy, DR, and EL groups, respectively. As summarized in Figure 2, some variability was observed in drop out patterns by teacher assignment. Families"
"who officially dropped out of the program were not evaluated at
posttest. Based on parents’ letters of withdrawal from the program,
the most frequent reasons cited were lack of time to participate in
parent coaching and change of residence.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"PEEP group sessions take place at a variety of easily accessible locations throughout the community. These are either based in the PEEP Center or at local playgroups, schools, and family centers. All sessions contain the same fundamental elements: Circle time: Music, rhyme, and rhythm are deeply embedded within the curriculum and are seen as "a powerful interactive medium in relationships" (PEEP, 2003). All families are offered audiotapes and a songbook containing the songs and rhymes used in the program. Talking time: An opportunity is provided for adults to discuss information and ideas, to share experiences, and to offer support. Story time: Daily sharing of books is a fundamental aspect of the curriculum and is modeled in every session. Book sharing: Books are available for parents to share with their children during the group sessions and to take home. Home activities: Practical suggestions are provided for games and activities that are closely related to and support the curriculum."
"Borrowing time: A library of play packs that contain a book and other stimulating materials are offered on a
weekly basis.
Throughout PEEP sessions, PEEP leaders model for parents the different ways of reading books to their children by
paying particular attention, for example, to (1) varying the tone of their voices, (2) reading the title of the story and
the names of authors and illustrators, (3) following the text with their ﬁnger, and (4) asking questions for
comprehension while they are reading the story. Parents are also encouraged to read to their children as much as
possible, and families are provided with a story pack on a weekly basis.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"PEEP set out its aim as being
to effect a positive change in the educational achievement of a community of children, especially in the ﬁeld of
literacy, by a series of interventions beginning at the time of the child's birth until his or her entry into school[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"PEEP had the following aims:
1. To promote parents' and carers' awareness of children's very early learning and development through making
the most of everyday activities and interactions.
2. To support parents/carers in their relationships with their children to enhance children's self-esteem.
3. To afﬁrm the crucial role of parents/carers as children's ﬁrst educators.
4. To support parents/carers in the development of their children's literacy and numeracy.
5. To support parents/carers so that they can encourage the development of positive learning dispositions.
6. To promote and support parents' and carers' lifelong learning.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"Dialogic reading involves families\nreading with their children rather than to their children[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"The aim of our study was to implement a dialogic reading
programme with a group of at-risk children in the year
prior to formal schooling, and to assess its effectiveness
by comparing literacy achievements in Year 1 of the
experimental group with the literacy achievements of a
control group of children who were similarly at risk of
reading failure.[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"video\nrecording was developed by one of the authors[¬e]"']
int_training_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"An initial meeting with each experimental group family
took place in the family home. A trained research assistant
presented the families with videotaped instruction
exemplifying good practice in dialogic reading. This video
recording was developed by one of the authors in a pilot
study reported elsewhere (Fielding-Barnsley, 2000). Three
families are shown on the videotape, with each family
concentrating on a different aspect of dialogic reading.
There are examples emphasising rhyme, vocabulary and
CAP. Each family also received written information about
the dialogic reading process, thereby extending the visual
information provided on the videotape. This was in the form
of a four-page pamphlet developed by The University of
New England School of Psychology’s Early Literacy
Team (Byrne, Fielding-Barnsley, Delaland, Mackay and
Black, 1999). This pamphlet contains sections on: ‘How to
promote pre-reading skills in your child; Read with your
child; Let your child tell the story; Play with speech
sounds: Rhyme and alliteration; Teach your child about
the alphabet; and Teach your child about the sounds
that make up words … and how letters stand for these
sounds.’[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"Each family was provided with a selection of eight picture
books, a Parents’ Handbook (Barrs and Ellis, 1998), and a
reading together record form. The books were selected
from The Reading Together Series (Barrs and Ellis, 1998)
and included a variety of genres: rhyme, fictional stories,
factual texts, alphabet books and traditional songs. The
books were selected to fulfil the requirements of the study
in that they provided for development of rhyme awareness
(phonological awareness), alphabet knowledge, alliteration
(phonemic awareness) and rich vocabulary.[¬e]"']
int_part_info: intervention was training for parents on dialogue between themselves and their children to aid language development
int_approach_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"videotaped instruction\nexemplifying good practice in dialogic reading[¬e]"']
int_when_info: when the child was at home
int_who_info: the intervention is parent led tuition
int_dur_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"Families were asked to read each book with their child at\nleast five times during the eight-week intervention.[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"Each experimental family was asked to read each of
eight books with their children at least five times during the
eight-week intervention (requiring reading 1.4 books per
day). The average number of readings per book was 6.5[¬e]"']
int_leng_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"In most cases a parent did most reading at the
children’s bedtime but older siblings also did some after
school[¬e]"']
int_fidel_info: Only provides counts of number of books read, no details of fidelity of intervention to instructions
out_eval_ht:
['Page 2:

method developed by Arnold and Whitehurst (1994) and
Whitehurst et al. (1994) known as dialogic reading.[¬e]"']
base_diff_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"Table 2. Test results (means and standard deviations) for experimental and control groups at Times 1 and 2"\n"Time 1[¬e]"']

int_name_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"Parent-delivered compensatory education for
children at risk of educational failure[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"Let’s Play in Tandem[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"scaffolded educational
activities delivered at home by their mothers[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"third birthday and continued for 12 months. During this time, they participated in
educational activities in partnership with their mothers that were intended to develop
pre-reading skills (e.g., phonological awareness, perceptual discrimination), basic
numerical skills (e.g., understanding of size and quantity, counting to 10), and general
knowledge."
"All activities took the form of enjoyable games that were designed to elicit
sustained one-on-one verbal interactions, a joint focus of attention, and scaffolding
of the children’s learning. In accordance with the deﬁnition of scaffolding provided
by Wood, Bruner, and Ross (1976), mothers’ role in such activities was therefore to
provide children with prompts, demonstrations, instructions, and encouragement to
complete the tasks.[¬e]"']

and in line with its objectives (Glass, 1999)"
"Let’s Play in Tandem was inspired by an earlier intervention programme along
similar lines (Ford, Evans, & McDougall, 2003),"
"Our inclusion of the remaining
measures of cognitive development was motivated by evidence linking compensatory
education with beneﬁts to children’s vocabulary development (review by Duncan,
Ludwig, & Magnuson, 2007),[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 10:
[¬s]"In the Preschool program, children were offered a half-day (morning) of instruction with an optional free afternoon daycare. This amounts to 486 total hours of instruction during the academic year. The Preschool used the Cog-X curriculum, which we developed with a focus on math, literacy, self-regulation, and socio-emotional learning. Cog-X integrates reading, math, social studies, science, and socio-emotional activities throughout the day."
"Cog-X also puts a strong emphasis on parental involvement, primarily through bi-weekly
Parent Empowerment workshops. During Parent Empowerment, parents attend a group parent
class to learn from their own child’s teacher how to scaffold the child’s learning through activities
in the home. Parents whose children were randomized to the Preschool program received 21 parent
contact hours during the group classes.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"We present the results of a novel early childhood intervention in which disadvantaged 3-4-year-
old children were randomized to receive a new preschool and parent education program focused
on cognitive and non-cognitive skills (CogX) or to a control group that did not receive preschool
education.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"We were motivated by this research to design the Kinderprep program to occur during
the critical summer months where “summer loss” might commonly take place.[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht:
['Page 8:
[¬s]"Our experiments were conducted at the Chicago Heights Early Childhood Center (CHECC)
in 2012-2014. We founded CHECC in 2010 in Chicago Heights, Illinois in partnership with
Chicago Heights School District 170 (thereafter, SD170).[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: NA
int_part_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"Finally, our research is related to a literature on student learning throughout the year. This
research finds that students, especially students from disadvantaged backgrounds, tend to lose[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"knowledge and skills over the summer break (Downey, Von Hippel, and Broh, 2004; Cooper et
al., 1996).5 We were motivated by this research to design the Kinderprep program to occur during
the critical summer months where “summer loss” might commonly take place. We are also the
first to consider how learning proceeds throughout an academic year by considering the impact of
our program during both the mid-year (January) evaluation period and the end-year (May)
evaluation period.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"MOCEP is a family-enrichment education programme that promotes parenting skills and pre-readiness skills for children from the pre-entry level to primary school. The programme has two components, often referred to as ‘intergenerational’, because they provide two complementary training sessions simultaneously for mothers alongside their 5+-year-old children"
"Cognitive Training Programme (CTP) which provides
25 consecutive weeks of daily, home-based pre-readiness activities and exercises that
promote child development. Examples of the activities include: language, communi-
cation, numeracy, social-awareness-building skills, listening and observation skills
such as storytelling, guided reading materials with questions for comprehension,
matching, sorting/sequencing exercises, counting/measuring, fine motor co-ordination
exercises using familiar household objects for language/communications activities
and several gross motor movement exercises. The children are daily taught the
activities by their mothers in their respective homes."
"The second component of the programme is the Mother Support Programme
(MSP) which provides weekly lectures on effective parenting practices and awareness
of early childhood development. Some of the weekly topics include: the importance
of the pre-school years for learning and the mother’s role; characteristics of growth
and development in the developing child; cognitive development; some aspects of
personality development (1 and 2); the importance of play and its contribution to devel-
opment; safety–first aid and mother–child relationships. Participant mothers meet
weekly at conveniently located centres to attend a discussion followed by a practice
session working with the weekly CTP.[¬e]"']

Programme (MOCEP) which was developed in Turkey in the early 1980s by a team
of academic researchers. It was modelled, in part, after the HIPPY programme
(Lombard, 1981) and since has undergone revisions. In Turkey, the Turkish Ministry
of Education in collaboration with ACEV (The Mother Child Education Foundation)
serves thousands of families successfully every year with MOCEP (Kagitcibasi,
Sunar, Bekman, Baydar, & Cemalcilar, 2009).[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 9:
[¬s]"Parents in FAST schools became willing participants and en- joyed assisting their children with learning activities when they knew what to do. Uncertainty and insecurity of subject matter and a dearth of educational materials in the home were found to be the primary deterrents to adults reinforcing school instruction at home. This section of the workshop helped parents develop confidence in providing instructional assistance in homework assignments. Dur- ing the workshops, teachers"
"talk to parents about subject and content areas that are being taught,
• talk to parents about the instructional goals for each subject,
• inform parents of the instructional expectations for the upcoming
school month (this practice provides a framework for helping at
home until the next parent meeting),
• demonstrate and have parents participate in learning activities that
children will have in class,
• conduct make it/take it sessions so that parents will have materials
to reinforce instruction,
• provide student homework assignments for 2 to 4 weeks in advance,
and
• discuss and demonstrate how common household sights/goods and
typical drives or walks through the community can be used to
complete homework assignments or as teaching tools.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The FLPs in this study were designed based on the ORIM conceptual framework (Hannon, 1995; Nutbrown & Hannon, 1997), previously mentioned, which conceptualizes families as supporting their children’s literacy learning through providing Opportunities for learning, showing Recognition of children’s activities, Interaction with children in terms of literacy activities and providing a Model of a literacy user."
"The programs were activities-based, and included eight workshops/
sessions as follows: 1) the importance of family literacy in children’s
literacy development; 2) creating environmental print; 3) the im-
portance of books in children’s literacy development; 4) storybook and
storytelling strategies; 5) developing children’s oral language; 6)
writing in early years; 7) how to provide opportunities and recognition
to develop children’s literacy; and 8) how to provide interaction and a
model of literacy to develop children’s literacy. All workshop activities
was held in the kindergarten settings after the school day and on
weekends, where parents come to all of the sessions."
"Each workshop session lasted around one hour. In addition to these
workshops/sessions, regular parent-teacher meetings were held in the
kindergarten settings (the experimental group).[¬e]"']

their children’s literacy learning. Parents, as their children’s first (and
most important) teachers, should not be excluded in the process of

study is also vital because the Qatar National Development Strategy
emphasizes the importance of improving and fostering students’ lan-
guage and literacy skills and expanding parental involvement in schools
(The Qatar General Secretariat for Development Planning, 2011).[¬e]"']
